discussion_comments.comment_body:
We should add a comment here explaining why this file is being included here and is empty. I can see us forgetting why this is needed and accidentally deleting it. If this ever gets deleted, we will start inheriting from the furo as mentioned below which we don't want to happen:
> Sphinx will look for templates in the folders of [templates_path](https://www.sphinx-doc.org/en/master/usage/configuration.html#confval-templates_path) first, and if it can’t find the template it’s looking for there, it falls back to the selected theme’s templates.

Source: https://www.sphinx-doc.org/en/master/development/html_themes/templating.html#templating-primer

commented_code:
+<!-- DO NOT REMOVE THIS FILE
+
+This file is normally inherited from the version defined by our docs theme (Furo).
+However, that file includes in-line styling which isn't allowed by our website's
+Content Security Policy (CSP). To resolve this issue, we've copied over the styling changes
+to `docs/source/_static/css/dark_light_mode.css`. Although this file is empty, it overwrites
+the template inherited from Furo. 
+
+ -->

discussion_comments.comment_body:
We should make this a jinja comment and not html comment as shown in the example below:

```
{#
  DO NOT REMOVE THIS FILE

  This file is normally inherited from the version defined by our docs theme (Furo).
  However, that file includes in-line styling which isn't allowed by our website's
  Content Security Policy (CSP). To resolve this issue, we've copied over the styling changes
  to `docs/source/_static/css/dark_light_mode.css`. Although this file is empty, it overwrites
  the template inherited from Furo. 
#}
```
This will prevent this comment from being rendered in every html page we generate
